term.name: American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials
term.shortDefinition: An interest group based in Washington, D.C., whose membership is involved in research, advocacy and technical assistance.
term.extDefinition: The American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials' membership includes state and territorial highway and transportation departments and agencies and the U.S. Department of Transportation. Its goal is to develop and improve methods of administration, design, construction, operation, and maintenance of a nationwide integrated transportation system. It studies transportation problems, advises Congress on legislation, and develops standards and policies.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Accessibility
term.shortDefinition: The extent to which facilities are barrier free and useable by persons with disabilities, including wheelchair users.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: americans with disabilities act
term.shortDefinition: Federal civil rights legislation for disabled persons passed in 1990; calls on public transit systems to make their services more fully accessible as well as to underwrite a parallel network of paratransit service.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Advanced Design Bus
term.shortDefinition: A bus introduced in 1977 that incorporates new styling and design features compared to previous buses.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: advanced public transportation system
term.shortDefinition: Refers to a wide range of advanced electronics and communications technology applied to roads and vehicles.
term.extDefinition: Also known as "smart cars," "smart streets" and even "smart buses," it promises to move the daily commute from the era of the Flinstones to the age of the Jetsons, from frustration-filled gridlock to computer guided navigation. The term refers to a wide range of advanced electronics and communications technology applied to roads and vehicles. Designed to improve safety and productivity, IVHS also can have a positive impact on air quality by cutting congestion. When the term is applied to transit, it is called APTS; in commercial trucking, it is referred to as CVO. The European especially seem to stretch the limits of the English language to come up with clever names for the nearly endless IVHS programs that have been spawned of late: DRIVE (Dedicated Road Infrastructure for Vehicle Safety in Europe) is a European Community-sponsored IVHS program that contains within it CIDER (Communication Infrastructure for DRIVE on European Roads), PAMELA (Pricing and Monitoring Electronically of Automobiles), PANDORA (Prototyping a Navigation Database of Road Network Attributes) and SOCRATES (System of Cellular Radio for Traffic Efficiency and Safety).
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Advanced Traffic Management Systems
term.shortDefinition: A high-tech version of the old-fashion traffic cop, ATMS uses a variety of means to more efficiently manage traffic. It can include roadside sensors, ramp metering, HOV lanes and synchronized traffic signals that respond to traffic flows.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Advanced Traveler Information Systems
term.shortDefinition: No more fumbling with the map, no more dreading unknown traffic hazards that lurk ahead of you -- these innovations provide travelers with information to help in trip planning and changing course en route to bypass congestion, e.g., broadcast traffic reports, in-car computerized maps and highway CMSs. Also can include automated transit trip planning and automated rideshare matching.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Advanced Vehicle Control Systems
term.shortDefinition: AVCS spans the gamut from ordinary cruise control to "smart cruise control" that helps maintain safe following distance to, researchers hope, "platooning" -- the ability to electronically link and guide a dense pack of cars moving in formation at high speed.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: advocacy organization
term.shortDefinition: A group of people actively working towards a specific goal on a specific issue.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Aerial Tramway
term.shortDefinition: An electric system of aerial cables with suspended unpowered passenger vehicles. The vehicles are propelled by separate cables attached to the vehicle suspension system and powered by engines or motors at a central location not on board the vehicle.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: agency coordination
term.shortDefinition: The process of allowing government agencies review and comment on transportation proposals
term.creator: admin

source.citation: "Multi-agency Coordination." Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia. 7 May 2006, 16:17 UTC. Wikimedia Foundation, Inc. 18 Jul 2006

term.name: agenda
term.shortDefinition: A list of things to be done or considered
term.extDefinition: Agendas usually appear in the context of a meeting, or other deliberative process. They are an attempt to list all of the issues that are to be addressed in a specific meeting, and also to put them in some meaningful order. An agenda is usually created before the meeting and given to participants to help them prepare. There is another sense of the term: An agenda can also be an underlying ideological plan that motivates some actions.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: "Agenda." Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia. 29 Jun 2006, 23:30 UTC. Wikimedia Foundation, Inc. 12 Jul 2006
American Heritage Dictionary,4th ed.
Merriam-Webster Online Dictionary

term.name: air quality
term.shortDefinition: A measure of the degree to which air is free from pollutants.
term.extDefinition: Air quality is often measured with the Environmental Protection Agency's AQI (Air Quality Index), which considers air pollutants to be almost any substance, natural or artificial, which has the potential to become airborne. On the AQI scale, pollutants are counted and measured in parts per billion.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Alaskan Way viaduct
term.shortDefinition: An elevated section of SR-99, running along the waterfront in downtown Seattle.
term.extDefinition: Many consider the existing viaduct to be aging and potentially unsafe in the event of an earthquake, and the issue of its replacement has been hotly debated.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: "Alaskan Way Viaduct." Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia. 6 Jul 2006, 16:57 UTC. Wikimedia Foundation, Inc. 12 Jul 2006

term.name: Alternative Analysis
term.shortDefinition: An analysis of the engineering and financial feasibility of alternatives under consideration for a rail extension or other major transit construction project; required before federal monies can be allocated to a project.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Alternative Fuels
term.shortDefinition: Low-polluting fuels which are used to propel a vehicle instead of high-sulfur diesel or gasoline. Examples include methanol, ethanol, propane or compressed natural gas, liquid natural gas, low-sulfur or "clean" diesel and electricity.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Amalgamated Transit Union
term.shortDefinition: A major labor union representing workers in the transit industry; membership is limited to operators, mechanics and other non-supervisory employees of the transit industry.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: American Public Transit Association
term.shortDefinition: The national, nonprofit trade association representing the public transit industry.
term.extDefinition: APTA members include more than 400 public transit systems, as well as state and local departments of transportation and planning agencies, manufacturers and suppliers of transit equipment, consultants, contractors and universities.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Annual Element
term.shortDefinition: Those transportation improvement projects, contained in an area's Transportation Improvement Program (TIP), that are proposed for implementation in the current year.
term.extDefinition: The annual element is submitted to the U.S. Department of Transportation (U.S. DOT) as part of the required planning process.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Apportionment
term.shortDefinition: A federal budgetary term that refers to a statutorily prescribed division or assignment of funds. It is based on prescribed formulas in the law and consists of dividing authorized obligation authority for a specific program among transit systems.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Appropriation
term.shortDefinition: A federal budgetary term that refers to an act of Congress that permits federal agencies to incur obligations and make payments out of the Treasury for specified purposes.
term.extDefinition: An appropriation act is the most common means of providing budget authority, but in some cases the authorization legislation itself provides the budget authority.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Arbitration
term.shortDefinition: A method of settling disputes where labor and management present their case to an impartial third party, called an arbitrator, who has the responsibility of deciding the case.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Arterial
term.shortDefinition: A major thoroughfare, used primarily for through traffic rather than for access to adjacent land, that is characterized by high vehicular capacity and continuity of movement.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Articulated Bus
term.shortDefinition: A bus usually 55 feet or more in length with two connected passenger compartments that bend at the connecting point when the bus turns a corner.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: artifact
term.shortDefinition: A man-made object
term.extDefinition: Artifacts are things created by human beings, which do not occur through natural processes. Artifacts are usually physical objects, but they can often be intangible things as well. For instance, errors, mistakes, and misinterpretations that are the result of some flawed process are said to be artifacts of that process.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: American Heritage Dictionary, 4th ed.

term.name: Authorization
term.shortDefinition: Basic legislation which establishes or continues the legal operation of a federal program or agency, either indefinitely or for a specific period of time, or which sanctions a particular type of obligation or expenditure within a program. An authorization may set appropriation limits.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Automated Guideway
term.shortDefinition: An electric railway operating without vehicle operators or other crew on board the vehicle.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Automated Toll Collection
term.shortDefinition: Now even law-abiding commuters will be able to zoom past the toll takers. Sensors at toll booths will pick up billing information from devices installed in cars, allowing motorists to drive through without stopping; the amount of the toll is automatically deducted from a prepaid account or billed to the vehicle's owner. An application of AVI technology.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Automated Vehicle Identification
term.shortDefinition: It combines an in-car device as well as a roadside receiver that will identify for vehicles for purposes of automated toll collection, stolen vehicle recovery, etc.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Automated Vehicle Location System
term.shortDefinition: A system which employs satellites and other technologies to track vehicles in a fleet, assisting with dispatching and other applications.
term.extDefinition: Currently used by truckers and courier services, it could be used in the future by transit systems to provide real-time schedule information for patrons, and will help the CHP monitor FSP tow trucks.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Automatic Fare Collection System
term.shortDefinition: A system of controls and equipment that automatically admits passengers on insertion of the correct fare in coins, tokens, tickets or farecards; it may include special equipment for transporting and counting revenues.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Auto Restricted Zone
term.shortDefinition: An area in which normal automobile traffic is prohibited or limited to certain times, and vehicular traffic is restricted to public transit, emergency vehicles, taxicabs and, in some cases, delivery of goods.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Average Vehicle Occupancy
term.shortDefinition: The number of people on the road divided by the number of cars on the road.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Average Vehicle Ridership
term.shortDefinition: The ratio of people on the road to number of cars on the road. Used to measure efficiency, pollution, and energy consumption in a transportation network.
term.extDefinition: The ratio of all people traveling by any mode, including cars, buses, trains and bicycles (or telecommuting), in a given area during a given time period to the number of cars on the road. A key measure of the efficiency and effectiveness of a transportation network - the higher the AVR, the better you're doing in terms of energy consumption and air pollution.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: ballot measure
term.shortDefinition: A policy question that is to be voted on by ordinary citizens, rather than by the legislature.
term.extDefinition: The state constitution allows for questions of policy to be given directly to the electorate. The ballot measure will come about in several ways, for instance from a citizen initiative, or a legislative referendum. A ballot measure may be binding or non-binding.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Bargaining Agent
term.shortDefinition: A labor union designated by an appropriate government agency or recognized by the employer as the exclusive representative of all employees in the bargaining unit for purposes of collective bargaining.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Base Fare
term.shortDefinition: The price charged to one adult for one transit ride; excludes transfer charges, zone charges, express service charges, peak period surcharges and reduced fares.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Base Period
term.shortDefinition: The period between the morning and evening peak periods when transit service is generally scheduled on a constant interval. Also known as "off-peak period".
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: benefit
term.shortDefinition: Something that improves well-being or a positive impact on goals and objectives.
term.extDefinition: Benefits can be abstract, because it is difficult to quantify \"well-being\" in a way that is true all the time. However, discussing benefits in the context of transportation planning is perhaps most useful when some measurable criteria can be associated with them.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Meyer and Miller 2001, pg. 491
American Heritage Dictionary, 4th ed.

term.name: bicycle friendly
term.shortDefinition: Providing some features and practices that aid in the safe and convenient use of bicycles in transportation
term.extDefinition: Some features of a bicycle-friendly area include bike lanes, designated covered areas for bicycle parking, safety education for motorists and bicyclists, police enforcement of bicyclists' rights, and others.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: bike lane
term.shortDefinition: A designated section of an existing road where bicyclists have right-of-way.
term.extDefinition: Also known (in the United States) as a Class 2 bikeway.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Binding Arbitration
term.shortDefinition: Arbitration with a final and binding award, which is often enforceable in the courts.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: bond
term.shortDefinition: A certificate issued by a government or corporation to raise funds. The cost of the bond is promised to be repaid later, usually with interest.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: bridge toll
term.shortDefinition: A fee required for passage over a bridge.
term.extDefinition: Sometimes used to control traffic flow (based on the theory that, in order to pay the fee, some drivers will find alternate routes), but most often they are used to raise revenue.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Budget Authority
term.shortDefinition: A federal budgetary term that refers to legal authority given by Congress to federal agencies to make funds available for obligation or expenditure.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Budget Resolution
term.shortDefinition: A federal budgetary term that refers to a concurrent resolution passed by both Houses of Congress, but not requiring the signature of the President, setting forth the congressional budget for each of five fiscal years.
term.extDefinition: The budget resolution sets forth various budget total and functional allocations, and may include reconciliation instructions to designated House or Senate committees.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Bus
term.shortDefinition: A rubber-tired, self-propelled, manually-steered vehicle with fuel supply carried on board the vehicle.
term.extDefinition: Types include advanced design, articulated, charter, circulator, double deck, express, feeder, intercity, medium-size, new look, sightseeing, small, standard-size, subscription, suburban, transit and van.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Bus Discretionary Capital
term.shortDefinition: Federal funding granted under Section 3 of the Federal Transit Act (formerly known as the Urban Mass Transportation Act). These discretionary funds are used for bus-related construction projects or to replace, rehabilitate or purchase buses.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Bus Lane
term.shortDefinition: A street or highway lane intended primarily for buses, either all day or during specified periods, but sometimes also used by carpools meeting requirements set out in traffic laws.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Bus Shelter
term.shortDefinition: A building or other structure constructed near a bus stop, to provide seating and protection from the weather for the convenience of waiting passengers.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Bus Stop
term.shortDefinition: A place where passengers can board or alight from the bus, usually identified by a sign.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Busway
term.shortDefinition: Exclusive freeway lane for buses and carpools.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Clean Air Act
term.shortDefinition: Clean Air Act amendment of 1990. The comprehensive federal legislation which establishes criteria for attaining and maintaining the federal standards for allowable concentrations and exposure limits for various air pollutants; the act also provides emission standards for specific vehicles and fuels.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Cable Car
term.shortDefinition: An electric railway operating in mixed street traffic with unpowered, individually-controlled transit vehicles propelled by moving cables located below the street surface and powered by engines or motors at a central location not on board the vehicle.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Capital Assistance
term.shortDefinition: Financial assistance for transit capital expenses (not operating costs); such aid may originate with federal, local or state governments.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Capital Cost
term.shortDefinition: Costs of long-term assets of a public transit system such as property, buildings, vehicles, etc.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: capital improvement program
term.shortDefinition: An investment program intended to enhance performance of a transportation process, part of the RTIP
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Capital revenue
term.shortDefinition: Monies dedicated for new projects to cover one-time costs, such as construction of roads, transit lines and facilities or purchase of buses and rail cars.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Carpool
term.shortDefinition: An arrangement where two or more people share the use and cost of privately owned automobiles in traveling to and from pre-arranged destinations together.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Catenary
term.shortDefinition: An overhead contact wire system which supplies power from a central power source to an electric vehicle (such as a trolley bus; see "Bus, Trolley".
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Central Business District
term.shortDefinition: The downtown retail trade and commercial area of a city or an area of very high land valuation, traffic flow, and concentration of retail business offices, theaters, hotels and services.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Charter Bus
term.shortDefinition: A bus transporting a group of persons who, pursuant to a common purpose, and under a single contract at a fixed price, have acquired the exclusive use of a bus to travel together under an itinerary.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Circulator bus
term.shortDefinition: A bus serving an area confined to a specific locale, such as a downtown area or suburban neighborhood with connections to major traffic corridors.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Collective Bargaining
term.shortDefinition: Negotiations between labor union representatives and employers to reach agreement on a contract describing such matters as wages, hours and working conditions.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Commuter
term.shortDefinition: A person who travels regularly between home and work or school.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Commuter Rail
term.shortDefinition: Railroad local and regional passenger train operations between a central city, its suburbs and/or another central city.
term.extDefinition: It may be either locomotive-hauled or self-propelled, and is characterized by multi-trip tickets, specific station-to-station fares, railroad employment practices and usually only one or two stations in the central business district. Also known as "suburban rail".
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: commuting alternative
term.shortDefinition: A method of regular travel not dependent upon single occupancy vehicle usage.
term.extDefinition: Common commuting alternatives include transit, carpooling, walking, bicycling, and others. The ﾓalternativeﾔ in this case is to single occupancy vehicle commuting, for instance when one person drives to and from work in a car.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: competing transportation proposal
term.shortDefinition: Separate, even mutually-exclusive efforts to address the same transportation issue.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Compressed Natural Gas
term.shortDefinition: A substitute for gasoline or diesel fuel. It is considered to be an environmentally "clean" alternative to those fuels. It is made by compressing purified natural gas, and is typically stored and distributed in hard containers.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: "Compressed natural gas." Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia. 11 Jul 2006, 01:59 UTC. Wikimedia Foundation, Inc. 12 Jul 2006

term.name: Compulsory Arbitration
term.shortDefinition: Arbitration that is required by law.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Conciliation
term.shortDefinition: Efforts by an impartial third party to encourage agreement between a labor union and management by counseling each side and facilitating negotiations. Also known as "mediation".
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Conformity
term.shortDefinition: In relation to air quality, conformity is the ongoing process that ensures the planning for highway and transit systems, as a whole and over the long term, is consistent with the state air quality plans for attaining and maintaining health-based air quality standards.
term.extDefinition: Conformity is determined by metropolitan planning organizations (MPOs) and the U.S. Department of Transportation ( U.S. DOT ), and is based on whether transportation plans and programs meet the provisions of a State Implementation Plan. To achieve conformity with federal clean air requirements, transportation projects collectively must not worsen air quality.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Contract Authority
term.shortDefinition: A federal budgetary term that refers to a form of budget authority permitting obligations to be incurred in advance of appropriations.
term.extDefinition: Advance obligations, however, have been limited by the appropriations committees with obligation limitations.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Contraflow Lane
term.shortDefinition: Reserved lane for buses on which the direction of bus traffic is opposite to the flow of traffic on the other lanes.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: "Reversible lane." Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia. 12 Jul 2006, 09:17 UTC. Wikimedia Foundation, Inc. 18 Jul 2006

term.name: convenor
term.shortDefinition: A convener initiates a decision situation, and serves as its sponsor who has the authority to covene a decision situation, e.g., the TIP manager at PSRC.
term.extDefinition: A convener is a person who has authority to invite people to participate in the transportation improvement decision process, and to establish the timeframe for carrying out the decision process. A convener is responsible for making sure that all who should participate are invited to participate, for suggesting an initial agenda that addresses all aspects of the transportation improvement decision situation, for reviewing input from others, and for approving the final version.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: "Convenor", in WordNet 2.1, Princeton University, 2005.

term.name: Corridor
term.shortDefinition: A broad geographical band that follows a general directional flow connecting major sources of trips that may contain a number of streets, highways and transit route alignments.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: cost
term.shortDefinition: The resources that need to be spent in order to construct or operate some part of a project.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Meyer and Miller 2001, ppg. 462,463)

term.name: Cost-of-Living Allowance
term.shortDefinition: An increase or decrease in employees' wages or salaries made on the basis of changes in agreed-upon economic indices, usually the Consumer Price Index.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: criterion
term.shortDefinition: The specific measure or test which reflects the degree of attainment of particular objectives.
term.extDefinition: Criteria result directly from the fact that the levels of attainment of the objectives of urban transportaiton planning are measurable. The derivation of criteria should be relatively straightforward if the goal set is properly defined. Criteria include the quantitative tests which are applied to alternative physical system plans in order to determine the degree to which they meet the stated objectives, and to compare alternative systems so that the one which most closely meets these objectives may be selected.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Meyer and Miller (2001) pg. 213
Wachs and Schofer (1969)

term.name: Crosstown
term.shortDefinition: Non-radial bus or rail service which does not enter the Central Business District
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Deadhead
term.shortDefinition: The movement of a transit vehicle without passengers aboard; often to and from a garage or to and from one route to another.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: decision/policy manager
term.shortDefinition: A person with decision/policy manager role has authority to indicate who can participate. A person with decision/policy manager role has responsibility to convene a decision process, if this person is employed in the sponsor or has been appointed to do so by the sponsor (authorized) organization, and to clarify the constraints on the process.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Dedicated Funding Source
term.shortDefinition: A source of monies which by law is available for use only to support a specific purpose, and cannot be diverted to other uses.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Demand Responsive
term.shortDefinition: Non-fixed-route service utilizing vans or buses with passengers boarding and alighting at pre-arranged times at any location within the system's service area. Also called "Dial-a-Ride".
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Department of Transportation
term.shortDefinition: The federal cabinet-level agency with responsibility for highways, mass transit, aviation and ports; headed by the secretary of transportation.
term.extDefinition: The DOT includes the Federal Highway Administration and the Federal Transit Administration, among others. There are also state DOTs (WashDOT in Washington)
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Dial-a-Ride
term.shortDefinition: Non-fixed-route service utilizing vans or buses with passengers boarding and alighting at pre-arranged times at any location within the system's service area. Also called "Demand Responsive"
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: disability access
term.shortDefinition: Provisions made to assist people with disabilities in using some aspect of the transportation system.
term.extDefinition: The Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 states that it is illegal to discriminate on the basis of a disability, and this is taken to legally guarantee that reasonable accomodations will be made to aid in the use of the transportation system. Disability access features can include elevator ramps on buses, audio signals at crosswalks, and others.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: "Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990." Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia. 11 Jul 2006, 11:41 UTC. Wikimedia Foundation, Inc. 12 Jul 2006

term.name: Disadvantaged Business Enterprise
term.shortDefinition: A business owned and operated by one or more socially and economically disadvantaged individuals.
term.extDefinition: Socially and economically disadvantaged individuals include African Americans, Hispanic Americans, Native Americans, Asian Pacific Americans or Asian Indian Americans and any other minorities or individuals found to be disadvantaged by the Small Business Administration under Section 8(a) of the Small Business Act.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Discretionary Spending
term.shortDefinition: A federal budgetary terms that refers to any funds whose distribution in not automatic. Discretionary spending encompasses programs controlled by annual appropriations bills and is subject to the constraints imposed by the discretionary spending limits set in the balanced budget law.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: domain
term.shortDefinition: A particular environment, or walk of life.
term.extDefinition: Describes things which fall under the same sphere, in a very broad sense. For example, a \"social\" domain would include everything about our casual and intimate relations with other people in society, a \"business\" domain would include everything related to our dealings in work and commerce. While the usefulness of a domain is in distinguishing between categories of things, domains, in practice, often overlap.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Double deck bus
term.shortDefinition: A bus with two separate passenger compartments, one above the other.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Downtime
term.shortDefinition: A period during which a vehicle is inoperative because of repairs or maintenance.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Downtown People Mover
term.shortDefinition: A type of automated guideway transit vehicle operating on a loop or shuttle route within the Central Business District ( CBD ) of a city.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Dwell Time
term.shortDefinition: The scheduled time a vehicle or train is allowed to discharge and take on passengers at a stop, including opening and closing doors.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Earmark
term.shortDefinition: A federal budgetary term that refers to the specific designation by Congress that part of a more general lump-sum appropriation be used for a particular project; the earmark can be designated as a minimum and/or maximum dollar amount.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: economic development
term.shortDefinition: Development in the economy of a region.
term.extDefinition: Usually (but not necessarily) implies the improvement of a regional economy, to the benefit of its citizens.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: elected decision maker
term.shortDefinition: A person with elected official role has authority to make a final decision. A person with elected official role has responsibility to review recommendations and make final decisions.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Electronic Toll Collection
term.shortDefinition: Now even law-abiding commuters will be able to zoom past the toll takers. Sensors at toll booths will pick up billing information from devices installed in cars, allowing motorists to drive through without stopping; the amount of the toll is automatically deducted from a prepaid account or billed to the vehicle's owner. An application of AVI technology.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Employee Transportation Coordinator
term.shortDefinition: Someone designated by a business or organization to assist its workers with forming carpools and vanpools, plotting their commute by public transit, and the like.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: employment density
term.shortDefinition: A measure of the number of people employed in a predefined location.
term.extDefinition: Usually, employment density is measured either in parcel density, which is the number of employees in a given area of land (for instance, acres, blocks, or square miles), or in building density, which is essentially its opposite (the amount of space there is for each worker in a particular area). It is a measurement of how efficiently an area of land is being used commercially, and can help in transportation planning by (for instance) informing how streets and bus routes are planned around commuting traffic.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: environmental impact study
term.shortDefinition: An analysis of the environmental impacts of proposed land development and transportation projects.
term.extDefinition: Sometimes called an Enviromental Impact Report (EIR) or Environmental Impact Statement. They are usually prepared prior to making a final decision about development of, and a draft of the study will be circulated for public notice and commentary. Generally, impact studies discuss how construction, production, or development on a project will affect the environment (positively and negatively) of the area in question.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Ethanol
term.shortDefinition: An alternative fuel; a liquid alcohol fuel with vapor heavier than air; produced from agricultural products such as corn, grain and sugar cane.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Exclusive Right-of-Way
term.shortDefinition: A highway or other facility that can only be used by buses or other transit vehicles.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Executive Order 12372
term.shortDefinition: A presidential directive that furnishes guidance to federal agencies for cooperation with state and local governments in the evaluation, review and coordination of federal assistance programs and projects.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Express bus
term.shortDefinition: A bus that operates a portion of the route without stops or with a limited number of stops.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Fare Box Recovery Ratio
term.shortDefinition: Measure of the proportion of operating expenses covered by passenger fares; found by dividing fare box revenue by total operating expenses for each mode and/or systemwide.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Fare Box Revenue
term.shortDefinition: Value of cash, tickets, tokens and pass receipts given by passengers as payment for rides; excludes charter revenue.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Fare Elasticity
term.shortDefinition: The extent to which ridership responds to fare increases or decreases.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Fare Structure
term.shortDefinition: The system set up to determine how much is to be paid by various passengers using a transit vehicle at any given time.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Federal Implementation Plan
term.shortDefinition: When you don't do your SIP as required by the CAA, you get "FIPped," which means the feds step in and do one for you.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Federal Transit Administration
term.shortDefinition: A federal agency responsible for providing funding assistance for transit services.
term.extDefinition: (Or FTA) Formerly known as the Urban Mass Transportation Administration (UMTA); FTA is the agency of the U.S. Department of Transportation which administers the federal program of financial assistance to public transit. (APTA)
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Federal Transit Funding Equity
term.shortDefinition: A ratio of appropriated dollars between Sections 9 and 18 (formula funds) to Section 3 (discretionary funds).
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Feeder bus
term.shortDefinition: A bus service that picks up and delivers passengers to a rail rapid transit station or express bus stop or terminal.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Ferry
term.shortDefinition: A boat providing fixed-route service across a body of water.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Fiscal Year
term.shortDefinition: The yearly accounting period for the federal government which begins October 1 and ends on the following September 30.
term.extDefinition: The fiscal year is designated by the calendar year in which it ends (e.g., FY 06 is from October 1, 2005 to September 30, 2006).
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Fixed Cost
term.shortDefinition: An indirect cost that remains relatively constant, irrespective of the level of operational activity.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Fixed Guideway System
term.shortDefinition: A system of vehicles that can operate only on its own guideway constructed for that purpose (e.g., rapid rail, light rail).
term.extDefinition: Federal usage in funding legislation also includes exclusive right-of-way bus operations, trolley coaches and ferryboats as "fixed guideway" transit.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Fixed Route
term.shortDefinition: Service provided on a repetitive, fixed-schedule basis along a specific route with vehicles stopping to pick up and deliver passengers to specific locations; each fixed-route trip serves the same origins and destinations, unlike demand responsive and taxicabs.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Flexible funding
term.shortDefinition: Unlike funding that flows only to highways or only to transit by a rigid formula, this is money that can be invested on a range of transportation projects.
term.extDefinition: Examples of flexible funding programs include the Surface Transportation Program, Congestion Mitigation and Air Quality Improvement, and Flexible Congestion Relief.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Flexible Funds
term.shortDefinition: Those federal funds which can be used for highway, transit or other transportation projects, as decided by regional Metropolitan Planning Organizations (MPOs) and state governments.
term.extDefinition: Examples of such funds are the Surface Transportation Program (STP) and the Congestion Mitigation and Air Quality (CMAQ) fund.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Formula Funds
term.shortDefinition: Funds distributed or apportioned to qualifying recipients on the basis of formulas described in law;
term.extDefinition: For example, funds in the Section 18 program for Small Urban and Rural Transit Assistance, which are distributed to each state based on the state's percentage of national rural population.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Fringe Parking
term.shortDefinition: An area for parking usually located outside the Central Business District (CBD) and most often used by suburban residents who work or shop downtown.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: funding option
term.shortDefinition: The ways in which money for transportation projects can be raised or alloted.
term.extDefinition: Includes money from the existing general tax fund, as well as new taxes, bonds, levies, tolls, et cetera. May also refer to private investments in some cases. Funding options may also be of various durations and schedules, from immediate to long-term.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: funding package
term.shortDefinition: A set of funds for a particular project.
term.extDefinition: A funding package is a fixed or variable amount of capital given or set aside for a particular project.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: funding source
term.shortDefinition: A means of getting money for a project.
term.extDefinition: Projects may have multiple funding sources, and funding sources may take a variety of forms. Taxes, fees, donations, investments by individuals, groups, or corporations, et cetera, are all examples of funding sources.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: gas tax
term.shortDefinition: A sales tax applied to fuel.
term.extDefinition: A gas tax is a specific tax applied to the sale of fuel, usually gasoline at a filling station. Fuel is taxed at a fixed rate based on the amount sold. The money raised from the tax is almost always allocated to transportation-related projects (often the maintenance and construction of roads).
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: goal
term.shortDefinition: The idealized state of affairs an objective is meant to bring about.
term.extDefinition: Goals derive from the shared values held by people, and they should lead to some specific objectives that can be completed in order to meet them. Goals are likely to be very vague -- for instance, \"improved safety\" is an example of a goal most people value. However, by themselves, goals cannot be measured, and so it is impossible to know when they have been attained. This is why specific objectives (and, in turn, criteria) are necessary.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Meyer and Miller (2001) pg. 212

term.name: grassroots activism
term.shortDefinition: A type of activism involving the participation of a community network of non-professional activists.
term.extDefinition: Grassroots activism usually begins at a local level, with a small community of interested, "ordinary" citizens, rather than with an existing group, or professional activists.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Grievance Arbitration
term.shortDefinition: The process of resolving a labor dispute involving the application or interpretation of a collective bargaining agreement, by asking an impartial third party to make a decision after both labor and management have presented their cases.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: growth management
term.shortDefinition: The use of specific techniques to ensure that the type, amount, and rate of development adheres to community known community goals.
term.extDefinition: Growth management techniques aim to make sure that the needs of a population will be met by the amount of services a city can provide, regardless of how that population grows. A growth management plan might call for zoning regulations that control the number of particular types of businesses in different parts of a city, or for impact fees that fund the creation of new parks, schools, transportation projects, etc.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: "Growth management." Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia. 27 May 2006, 07:37 UTC. Wikimedia Foundation, Inc. 18 Jul 2006

term.name: Headway
term.shortDefinition: Time interval between vehicles moving in the same direction on a particular route.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Heavy Rail
term.shortDefinition: An electric railway with the capacity for a "heavy volume" of traffic and characterized by exclusive rights-of-way, multi-car trains, high speed and rapid acceleration, sophisticated signaling and high platform loading.
term.extDefinition: Also known as "rapid rail," "subway," "elevated (railway)" or "metropolitan railway (metro)".
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: high occupancy toll lane
term.shortDefinition: Designated lanes or roadways for vehicles with numerous passengers, or for single occupancy vehicles that have paid a usage fee.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: High Speed Rail
term.shortDefinition: A rail transportation system with exclusive right-of-way which serves densely traveled corridors at speeds of 124 miles per hour (200 km/h) and greater.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Highway Advisory Radio
term.shortDefinition: "Chains required on Snoqualmie Summit." Sound familiar? It may not be a top 20 hit, but such radio warnings broadcast via a special frequency are music to the ears of drivers who want to prepare for, avoid altogether, hazardous or difficult road conditions ahead.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: highway capacity
term.shortDefinition: The number of cars a highway is expected to handle in a given length of time.
term.extDefinition: Usually, highway capacity is measured in cars per hour under normal weather and traffic flow conditions.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Highway Trust Fund
term.shortDefinition: The federal trust fund established by the Highway Revenue Act of 1956; this fund has two accounts -- the Highway Account and the Mass Transit Account. Trust fund revenues are derived from federal highway-user taxes and fees such as motor fuel taxes; trust fund uses and expenditures are determined by law.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: housing density
term.shortDefinition: The number of homes in a given area.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: I-405 Corridor
term.shortDefinition: A section of interstate highway passing through eastern King County
term.extDefinition: Also called the Renton Freeway. I-405 bypasses downtown Seattle, and is heavily used by Eastside commuters.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: "Interstate 405 (Washington)." Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia. 5 Jul 2006, 21:40 UTC. Wikimedia Foundation, Inc. 18 Jul 2006

term.name: impact
term.shortDefinition: The affects of some activity on people, an environment, a system, or a culture.
term.extDefinition: Includes both negative and positive impacts. Some activities have direct and immediate impacts, while other activities combine to have a cumulative impact.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Intelligent Vehicle-Highway System
term.shortDefinition: The term refers to a wide range of advanced electronics and communications technology applied to roads and vehicles, meant to improve safety and productivity.
term.extDefinition: Also known as "smart cars," "smart streets" and even "smart buses," it promises to move the daily commute from the era of the Flinstones to the age of the Jetsons, from frustration-filled gridlock to computer guided navigation. The term refers to a wide range of advanced electronics and communications technology applied to roads and vehicles. Designed to improve safety and productivity, IVHS also can have a positive impact on air quality by cutting congestion. When the term is applied to transit, it is called APTS; in commercial trucking, it is referred to as CVO. The European especially seem to stretch the limits of the English language to come up with clever names for the nearly endless IVHS programs that have been spawned of late: DRIVE (Dedicated Road Infrastructure for Vehicle Safety in Europe) is a European Community-sponsored IVHS program that contains within it CIDER (Communication Infrastructure for DRIVE on European Roads), PAMELA (Pricing and Monitoring Electronically of Automobiles), PANDORA (Prototyping a Navigation Database of Road Network Attributes) and SOCRATES (System of Cellular Radio for Traffic Efficiency and Safety).
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Intercity bus
term.shortDefinition: A bus with front doors only, high-backed seats, separate luggage compartments, and usually with restroom facilities for use in high-speed long-distance service.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Interest Arbitration
term.shortDefinition: The process of arriving at the terms of a new collective bargaining agreement, by asking an impartial third party to make rulings after both labor and management have presented their cases.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: interested/affected individual
term.shortDefinition: A person with interested/affected individuals role have authority to provide input on anything and everything, articulate/synthesize concerns, evaluate alternatives, and choose recommended alternatives. A person with interested/affected individuals role have responsibility to contribute as often as desired
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Intermodal
term.shortDefinition: Those issues or activities which involve or affect more than one mode of transportation, including transportation connections, choices, cooperation and coordination of various modes.
term.extDefinition: The term "mode" is used to refer to and to distinguish from each other the various forms of transportation, such as automobile, transit, ship, bicycle and walking. Intermodal refers specifically to the connections between modes.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act
term.shortDefinition: A $151 billion dollar piece of legislation signed into law in December, 1991, which proposed broad changes to the way transportation decisions are made. It emphasizes diversity and a balance between different modes of transportation over the construction of new roads.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Jitney
term.shortDefinition: Privately-owned, small or medium-sized vehicle usually operated on a fixed route but not on a fixed schedule.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Joint Development
term.shortDefinition: Ventures undertaken by the public and private sectors for development of land around transit stations or stops.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: King County Council
term.shortDefinition: A group composed of representatives from each district who act as legislators in county government.
term.extDefinition: Also called the Metropolitan King County Council. Currently has 13 members, responsible for enacting laws, policies, and setting an annual budget.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: King County Metro Web Site

term.name: King County Department of Transportation
term.shortDefinition: A part of county government responsible for operating the Metro transit system and maintaining roads.
term.extDefinition: KC-DOT is responsible for other services, such as the operation of King County International Airport (Boeing Field) and the maintenance of city vehicles.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: King County Metro Web site. Accessed 7/18/2005

term.name: Kiss and Ride
term.shortDefinition: A place where commuters are driven and dropped off at a station to board a public transportation vehicle.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Layover Time
term.shortDefinition: Time built into a schedule between arrival at the end of a route and the departure for the return trip, used for the recovery of delays and preparation for the return trip.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Level Playing Field
term.shortDefinition: A balanced approach to federal funding proportions for highway projects and transit projects.
term.extDefinition: May also refer to employee transportation benefits so that the monthly, tax-free value of a transit pass is equal to that of a parking space; generally, any situation in which transit and highways receive equal treatment in federal funding and other federal procedures.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: light rail
term.shortDefinition: A tram or trolley for mass transit that uses existing city streets, with some right-of-way.
term.extDefinition: Light rail is called "light" in order to distinguish it from other rail systems that carry more passengers, and require more exclusive infrastructure (monorails and passenger trains, for instance). Light rail generally shares the streets with pedestrians, buses, and automobiles, but has right-of-way for some or all of its length. Light rail cars are usually powered by electricity from overhead cables.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Light-Rail Transit
term.shortDefinition: Fixed guideway transportation mode that typically operates on city streets and draws its electric power from overhead wires.
term.extDefinition: Include streetcars, trolley cars and tramways. Differs from heavy rail -- which has a separated right of way, and includes commuter and intercity rail -- in that it has lighter passenger capacity per hour and more closely spaced stops.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Light-Rail Vehicle
term.shortDefinition: A type of rail vehicle, similar to a streetcar, that is generally smaller than a heavy rail vehicle. Light-rail vehicles may travel on ordinary city streets along with other vehicles, or on special right-of-way routes.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: "Light rail." Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia. 9 Jul 2006, 00:36 UTC. Wikimedia Foundation, Inc. 13 Jul 2006

term.name: Liquefied Natural Gas
term.shortDefinition: An alternative fuel; a natural gas cooled to below its boiling point of -260 degrees Fahrenheit so that it becomes a liquid; stored in a vacuum bottle-type container at very low temperatures and under moderate pressure.
term.extDefinition: LNG vapor is lighter than air.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: livable community
term.shortDefinition: A community designed with the needs of residents in mind.
term.extDefinition: According to the Washington State Dept. of Transportation's Livable Communities workgroup, a livable community is one which will "provide and promote civic engagement and a sense of place through safe, sustainable choices for a variety of elements that include housing, transportation, education, cultural diversity and enrichment and recreation."
term.creator: admin

source.citation: WS-DOT Livable Communities Workgroup, "Livable Communities Policy".

term.name: Load Factor
term.shortDefinition: The ratio of passengers actually carried versus the total passenger capacity of a vehicle.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Magnetic levitation
term.shortDefinition: This technology permits trains to move at high speed above a guideway on a cushion of air generated by magnetic force.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: major truck street
term.shortDefinition: An arterial street that accommodate the movement of large amounts of freight and heavytrucks.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Managers of Mobility
term.shortDefinition: Term for transit systems which expand their role to include services and approaches beyond traditional public transportation.
term.extDefinition: Examples of programs include ridesharing, high occupancy vehicle programs, public education on transit's benefits and integration of land use, air quality and transportation decisions; the phrase was developed as part of the industry's Transit 2000 policy effort undertaken in the late 1980s and early 1990s.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: mass transit
term.shortDefinition: Transportation by bus, rail, or other conveyance, either publicly or privately owned, which provides to the public general or special service on a regular and continuing basis.
term.extDefinition: Also known as "mass transportation," and "transit".
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Mass Transit Account
term.shortDefinition: The federal account, established by the Surface Transportation Assistance Act of 1982, into which a designated portion of the federal Highway Trust Fund revenue from motor fuel taxes is placed. This account is used for federal mass transportation assistance.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Mass Transportation
term.shortDefinition: Transportation by bus, rail, or other conveyance, either publicly or privately owned, which provides to the public general or special service on a regular and continuing basis.
term.extDefinition: Also known as "mass transit" and "transit".
term.creator: admin
