source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Mean Distance Between Failures
term.shortDefinition: The average distance in miles that a transit vehicle travels before failure of a vital component forces removal of that vehicle from service.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Mediation
term.shortDefinition: Efforts by an impartial third party to encourage agreement by counseling each side and facilitating negotiations.
term.extDefinition: Also known as "conciliation".
term.creator: admin

source.citation: "Mediation", in WordNet 2.1, Princeton University, 2005.

term.name: Medium-Size bus
term.shortDefinition: A bus from 29 to 34 feet in length.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: mega-project
term.shortDefinition: Defined by the US Federal Highway Administration as major infrastructure projects that cost more than US$1 billion, or projects of a significant cost that attract a high level of public attention or political interest because of substantial direct and indirect impacts on the community, environment, and budgets
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Methanol
term.shortDefinition: An alternative fuel; a liquid alcohol fuel with vapor heavier than air; primarily produced from natural gas.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Metropolitan Planning Organization
term.shortDefinition: A federally required transportation planning body responsible for the RTP and the TIP in its region; the governor designates an MPO in every urbanized area with a population of over 50,000.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: metropolitan transportation plan
term.shortDefinition: The result of the process of developing and discussing a city's official transportation strategy. Lists highway and transit and transit projects for which the region hopes to capture funds.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Minority Business Enterprise
term.shortDefinition: A business owned and operated by one or more individuals who are defined as minorities under U.S. Department of Transportation regulations. See also "disadvantaged business enterprise".
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: mobility of freight
term.shortDefinition: The ways in which large quantities of material can be transported in to, out of, and through a city
term.extDefinition: Includes truck, rail, and marine freight movement.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Modal Split
term.shortDefinition: A term which describes how many people use alternative forms of transportation. Frequently used to describe the percentage of people using private automobiles as opposed to the percentage using public transportation.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Monorail
term.shortDefinition: An electric railway in which a rail car or train of cars is suspended from or straddles a guideway formed by a single beam or rail. Most monorails are either heavy rail or automated guideway systems.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Multimodal
term.shortDefinition: Refers to the availability of multiple transportation options, especially within a system or corridor.
term.extDefinition: A concept embraced in ISTEA, a multimodal approach to transportation planning focuses on the most efficient way of getting people or goods from place to place, be it by truck, train, bicycle, automobile, airplane, bus, boat, foot or even a computer modem.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: National Association of Regional Councils
term.shortDefinition: The nationwide organization for MPOs, COGs and other such entities; based in Washington, D.C.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: National Highway System
term.shortDefinition: An approximately 155,000-mile network of roads called for in in ISTEA to provide an interconnected system of principal routes to serve major travel destinations and population centers.
term.extDefinition: Picks up where the Interstate Highway System left off.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Interstate Highway System
term.shortDefinition: A network of freeways in the United States authorized by the Federal-Aid Highway Act of 1956. The Interstate Highway System is a separate system within the larger National Highway System.
term.extDefinition: While Interstate highways usually receive substantial federal funding and comply to federal standards, they are owned, built, and operated by the states in which they are located.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: "Interstate Highway System." Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia. 13 Jul 2006, 16:10 UTC. Wikimedia Foundation, Inc. 13 Jul 2006

term.name: National Transportation System
term.shortDefinition: A proposal by the U.S. Transportation Secretary to integrate all aspects and modes of the transportation system into a single national system. The National Highway System is expected to be a subset of the larger, multimodal NTS.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: neighborhood
term.shortDefinition: A physical area with distinctive qualities, or a group of people who live in physical proximity to each other.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: American Heritage Dictionary, 4th Ed.

term.name: neighborhood impact
term.shortDefinition: Various ways in which a set of events can effect a neighborhood
term.extDefinition: A general term for the effects of a project, event, or other phenomena. There is no single list of ways in which neighborhoods can be impacted, but rising or falling crime rates, housing prices, and population are common examples. Often, the ways in which a particular neighborhood have been or could be effected by a project are made into a Neighborhood Impact Statement.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: New Look bus
term.shortDefinition: A bus with the predominant styling and mechanical equipment common to buses manufactured between 1959 and 1978.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: New Start
term.shortDefinition: Federal funding granted under Section 3(i) of the Federal Transit Act (formerly known as the Urban Mass Transportation Act).
term.extDefinition: These discretionary funds are made available for construction of a new fixed guideway system or extension of any existing fixed guideway system, based on cost-effectiveness, alternatives analysis results and the degree of local financial commitment.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: noise pollution
term.shortDefinition: Unwanted sound, usually man-made
term.extDefinition: Sound is considered to be noise pollution when it is louder than the ambient environmental sound in an area, and when it has some negative effect on listeners. Sound that is loud, persistent, and uncontrollable is a good example of what would be considered noise pollution. Automobiles, electronics, factories, air conditioners, barking dogs, concerts, and air conditioners are common sources of noise pollution, but this is by no means an exhaustive list.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: "Noise pollution." Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia. 13 Jul 2006, 11:07 UTC. Wikimedia Foundation, Inc. 13 Jul 2006.

term.name: Nonattainment Area
term.shortDefinition: Any geographic region of the United States that the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has designated as not attaining the federal air quality standards for one or more air pollutants, such as ozone and carbon monoxide.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: objective
term.shortDefinition: A specific example of something that must be achieved in order to reach a goal.
term.extDefinition: Objectives always have some reference to the physical world. An example of an objective would be a statement such as \"decreasing the commuting time between West Seattle and Downtown.\" This objective could derive from a general goal of improving traffic flow, for instance. Objectives are a necessary part of any plan to satisfy a goal. Likewise, specific criteria for judging whether or not an objective has been met are necessary to make objectives measurable, and thus useful.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Meyer and Miller, 2001 (p.212)

term.name: Obligation
term.shortDefinition: A federal budgetary term that refers to a binding agreement that will result in an outlay; an agreement by the federal government to pay for goods or services immediately or at some future time when the goods or services are delivered.
term.extDefinition: Also known as a "commitment".
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Obligation Limitation
term.shortDefinition: An organization that provides transportation services owned, operated, or subsidized by any municipality, county, regional authority, state, or other governmental agency, including those operated or managed by a private management firm under contract to the government agency owner.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Off-Peak Period
term.shortDefinition: Non-rush periods of the day when travel activity is generally lower and less transit service is scheduled.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Operating Assistance
term.shortDefinition: Financial assistance for transit operating expenses (not capital costs); such aid may originate with federal, local or state governments.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Operating Deficit
term.shortDefinition: The sum of all operating expenses minus operating revenues.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Operating Expense
term.shortDefinition: Monies paid in salaries, wages, materials, supplies and equipment in order to maintain equipment and buildings, operate vehicles, rent equipment and facilities and settle claims.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Operating Revenue
term.shortDefinition: Monies used to fund general, day-to-day costs of running transportation systems. For transit, costs include fuel, salaries and replacement parts; for roads, operating costs involve maintaining pavement, filling potholes, paying workers' salaries, and so forth.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Outlay
term.shortDefinition: Outlay A federal budgetary term that refers to a payment made to meet an obligation; the point at which an actual payment of money is made.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Paratransit
term.shortDefinition: Comparable transportation service required by the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) of 1990 for individuals with disabilities who are unable to use fixed-route transportation systems.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Park and Ride Lot
term.shortDefinition: Designated parking areas for automobile drivers who then board transit vehicles from these locations.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Particulate Trap
term.shortDefinition: A filter which removes a portion of the particulates (solids, soot, etc.) from a vehicle's exhaust stream and generally includes a regenerative unit and associated control system to burn the collected solids.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Passenger Miles
term.shortDefinition: The total number of miles traveled by passengers on transit vehicles; determined by multiplying the number of unlinked passenger trips times the average length of their trips.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Peak/Base Ratio
term.shortDefinition: The number of vehicles operated in passenger service during the peak period divided by the number operated during the base period.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Peak Period
term.shortDefinition: Morning and afternoon time periods when transit riding is heaviest.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: pedestrian
term.shortDefinition: A person who travels on foot or who uses assistive devices, such as a wheelchair, for mobility.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: persona
term.shortDefinition: Detailed fictional participants used in the planning and development process.
term.extDefinition: Personas are richly defined fictional participants with personal backgrounds, (mental model differences about interpretation of improvement projects would be most valuable), goals, motivations, values, etc. which are based on user research (interviews, etc.). Backgrounds, goals, motivations, values, can be unpacked into the various parameters.\n One component of a persona will be the role it plays in a decision process. Designing a system based on roles alone may result in developers making incorrect and/or unstated assumptions about the goals, motivations, values, etc. of the individuals who will play a given role in the decision situation. Introducing personas into the system design process will help to mitigate this problem by providing developers with richly defined individuals with explicitly stated motivations, values, etc. for whom they can design the system. In other words, personas will help us to link the system design to the goals of its users, hopefully resulting in a design that is relevant to the users and a more satisfying user experience.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: preference
term.shortDefinition: A strong liking of one thing over its alternatives.
term.extDefinition: Also, the act of choosing one thing over its alternatives.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: "Preference", in WordNet 2.1, Princeton University, 2005.

term.name: procedure
term.shortDefinition: A series of steps followed in a definite order to arrive at a result.
term.extDefinition: A procedure defines the tasks that need to be completed, and their order, but does not specify the exact actions that make up each step. In other words, the same procedure can be completed several times, and could look slightly different each time, even producing different results. In this sense it is somewhat open-ended, but also has some predictability and control.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: "Procedure." Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia. 14 Jun 2006, 12:03 UTC. Wikimedia Foundation, Inc. 13 Jul 2006
American Heritage Dictionary, 4th ed.
"Procedure", in WordNet 2.1, Princeton University, 2005.

term.name: Program
term.shortDefinition: To assign funds to a project that has been approved by city, state or other agency, or, a system of funding for implementing transportation projects or policies.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Propane
term.shortDefinition: An alternative fuel; a liquid petroleum gas (LPG) which is stored under moderate pressure and with vapor heavier than air; produced as a by-product of natural gas and oil production.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Public Transportation
term.shortDefinition: Transportation by bus, rail, or other conveyance, either publicly or privately owned, which provides to the public general or special service on a regular and continuing basis.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Puget Sound Regional Council
term.shortDefinition: The federally-mandated regional transportation agency for the central Puget Sound region.
term.extDefinition: The PSRC is a forum for state agencies and county, tribal, and municipal representatives to discuss issues related to transportation planning and economic development in the region. The PSRC is also responsible for funding some transportation projects that accord with its long-term transportation plan.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Rail Modernization
term.shortDefinition: Federal funding granted under Section 3(h) of the Federal Transit Act (formerly known as the Urban Mass Transportation Act).
term.extDefinition: These discretionary funds are distributed by a formula and made available to transit systems for improvements on fixed guideway systems that have been in service for at least seven years. Also known as "fixed guideway modernization".
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: rank
term.shortDefinition: The position of a person, place or thing in relation to others based on a property they all share.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Rapid Transit
term.shortDefinition: Rail or motorbus transit service operating completely separate from all modes of transportation on an exclusive right-of-way.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Recission
term.shortDefinition: A federal budgetary term that refers to the cancellation, in whole or part, of budget authority previously granted by Congress.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: referendum
term.shortDefinition: An issue to be voted on by citizens rather than legislators.
term.extDefinition: The state constitution specifies that any registered voter may demand, by process of petition, that any non-emergency legislative act be verified by voter approval prior to going into effect. Voter referendums may also come directly from the state legislature.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Regional Transportation Improvement Program
term.shortDefinition: Lists highway and transit and transit projects for which the region hopes to capture funds.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Regional Transportation Plan
term.shortDefinition: A weighty document, literally and figuratively, it is a multimodal blueprint to guide the region's long-term transportation development.
term.extDefinition: It is based on projections of growth and travel demand coupled with real-world financial assumptions. Required by state and federal law.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Regional Transportation Planning Agency
term.shortDefinition: A state designated agency responsible for preparing the RTP and RTIP; administering TDA and other tasks.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Reverse Commuting
term.shortDefinition: Movement in a direction opposite the main flow of traffic, such as from the central city to a suburb during the morning peak period.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Ridership
term.shortDefinition: The number of rides taken by people using a public transportation system in a given time period.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Ridesharing
term.shortDefinition: A form of transportation, other than public transit, in which more than one person shares the use of the vehicle, such as a van or car, to make a trip.
term.extDefinition: Also known as "carpooling" or "vanpooling".
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Rolling Stock
term.shortDefinition: The vehicles used in a transit system, including buses and rail cars.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Route Miles
term.shortDefinition: The total number of miles included in a fixed route transit system network.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: scenario
term.shortDefinition: An outline of an expected sequence of events
term.extDefinition: A scenario describes what might happen, or what is expected to happen, but not what has to happen. It is different from a procedure in that it is less rigid; whereas a procedure contains steps that must each be engaged, and their order, the scenario only sets up a situation, and then relinquishes control.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: American Heritage Dictionary, 4th ed.

term.name: Section 13(c)
term.shortDefinition: The section of the Federal Transit Act (formerly known as the Urban Mass Transportation Act of 1964), as amended, related to labor protection that is designed to protect transit employees against a worsening of their position with respect to their employment as a result of grant assistance under the Act.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Section 15
term.shortDefinition: The section of the Federal Transit Act (formerly known as the Urban Mass Transportation Act of 1964), as amended, that authorizes the U.S. Department of Transportation to gather statistical information about the financing and operations of public transportation systems, based upon a uniform system of accounts and records.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Section 16
term.shortDefinition: The section of the Federal Transit Act (formerly known as the Urban Mass Transportation Act of 1964), as amended, that declares the national policy to be that elderly persons and persons with disabilities have the same right as other persons to utilize mass transportation facilities and services...
term.extDefinition: The section of the Federal Transit Act (formerly known as the Urban Mass Transportation Act of 1964), as amended, that declares the national policy to be that elderly persons and persons with disabilities have the same right as other persons to utilize mass transportation facilities and services, and that special efforts shall be made in the planning and design of mass transportation facilities and services so that effective utilization by elderly persons and persons with disabilities is assured.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Section 16(b)
term.shortDefinition: A subsection of the Federal Transit Act related to funding elderly and disability provisions on public transportation.
term.extDefinition: The subsection of the Federal Transit Act (formerly known as the Urban Mass Transportation Act of 1964), as amended, that authorizes grants to nonprofit corporations and associations for the specific purpose of assisting them in providing transportation services meeting the special needs of elderly persons and persons with disabilities for whom mass transportation services are unavailable, insufficient or inappropriate.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Section 18
term.shortDefinition: The section of the Federal Transit Act (formerly known as the Urban Mass Transportation Act of 1964), as amended, that authorizes grants to public transit systems outside urbanized areas, based on formulas set out in statute; the funds go initially to the Governor of each state.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Section 9
term.shortDefinition: The section of the Federal Transit Act (formerly known as the Urban Mass Transportation Act of 1964), as amended, that authorizes grants to public transportation systems in urbanized areas (population greater than 50,000) for both capital and operating programs based on formulas set out in statute.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Sequestration
term.shortDefinition: A federal budgetary term that refers to the permanent cancellation of budget authority.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Short Range Transit Plan
term.shortDefinition: A nine-year comprehensive plan required of all transit operators by federal and regional transportation funding agencies.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Shuttle
term.shortDefinition: A public or private vehicle that travels back and forth over a particular route, especially a short route or one that provides connections between transportation systems, employment centers, etc.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Sightseeing bus
term.shortDefinition: A bus adapted for sightseeing use, usually with expanded window areas.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Single-Occupancy Vehicle
term.shortDefinition: A vehicle with one occupant, the driver, who is sometimes referred to as a "drive alone."
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Small bus
term.shortDefinition: A bus 28 feet or less in length.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: standard
term.shortDefinition: The minimum acceptable level of attainment of a criteria.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: (Meyer and Miller, 2001, pg. 213)

term.name: Standard-Size bus
term.shortDefinition: A bus from 35 to 41 feet in length.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: State Implementation Plan
term.shortDefinition: Here's a case where one term refers to two different - albeit related - documents. Metropolitan areas prepare regional SIPs showing steps they plan to take to meet federal air quality standards (outlined in the Clean Air Act). Several SIPs make up the statewide plan for cleaning up the air, also known as a SIP.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Subscription bus
term.shortDefinition: A commuter bus express service operated for a guaranteed number of patrons from a given area on a prepaid, reserved-seat basis.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Suburban bus
term.shortDefinition: A bus with front doors only, normally with high-backed seats, and without luggage compartments or restroom facilities for use in longer-distance service with relatively few stops.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Supplemental Appropriation
term.shortDefinition: An act appropriating funds in addition to those in an annual appropriation act because the need for funds is too urgent to be postponed until enactment of the next regular appropriation act.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Surface Transportation Policy Project
term.shortDefinition: A coalition representing transportation, planning, architectural, energy, environmental and historic preservation interests whose goal is to develop a national transportation policy that, in its words, "better serves the environmental, social and economic interests of the nation."
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Tech support
term.shortDefinition: A person with techsupport role has authority to clarify technical questions about use of data, software, and hardware. A person with techsupport role has responsibility to suggest fixes for software and hardware.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Transportation Management Plan
term.shortDefinition: A required document which shows how traffic flows will be smoothed or diverted during the construction or alteration of a roadway.
term.extDefinition: For example, a TMP might call for installing ramp meters or upgrading parallel roads; boosting public transit service; aggressively marketing carpooling vanpooling; and mounting a public information campaign.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Transfer Center
term.shortDefinition: A fixed location where passengers interchange from one route or vehicle to another.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Transit
term.shortDefinition: Transportation by bus, rail, or other conveyance, either publicly or privately owned, which provides to the public general or special service on a regular and continuing basis.
term.extDefinition: Also known as "mass transit" and "mass transportation".
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Transit bus
term.shortDefinition: A bus with front and center doors, normally with a rear-mounted engine, low-back seating, and without luggage compartments or restroom facilities for use in frequent-stop service.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Transit System
term.shortDefinition: An organization (public or private) providing local or regional multi-occupancy-vehicle passenger service. Organizations that provide service under contract to another agency are generally not counted as separate systems.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Transportation Control Measure
term.shortDefinition: Strategy to reduce driving or smooth traffic flows in order to cut auto emissions. Required by the Clean Air Act.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Transportation Demand Management
term.shortDefinition: Low-cost ways to reduce demand by automobiles on the transportation system, such as programs to promote telecommuting, flextime and ridesharing.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Transportation Enhancement Activities
term.shortDefinition: Projects that enhance the compatibility of transportation facilities with their surroundings.
term.extDefinition: An ISTEA created funding category. Ten percent of STP monies must be set aside for projects that enhance the compatibility of transportation facilities with their surroundings. Examples of TEA projects include bicycle and pedestrian paths, restoration of rail depots or other historic transportation facilities, acquisition of scenic or open space lands next to travel corridors, and murals or other public art projects.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: transportation equity
term.shortDefinition: The degree to which transportation services are distributed appropriately and fairly.
term.extDefinition: Transportation equity depends on how a particular group of people are effected by transportation services, either positively or negatively. Transportation equity depends greatly on the population being considered ﾖ services that are thought to be equitably distributed in one group (for instance, a social or economic group) may be recognized as less equitable in another. The Transportation Equity Act for the 21st Century (TEA ﾖ 21) provides federal money to help aid in assuring transportation equity.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Transportation Improvement Program
term.shortDefinition: This is primarily a spending plan for federal funding expected to flow to the region from all sources for transportation projects of all types.
term.extDefinition: The TIP is prepared annually with the cooperation of local governments, transit operators and WashDOT. Depending on the funding source it covers a three- to seven-year period.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: transportation information specialist
term.shortDefinition: A person with transportation information specialist role has authority to address technical questions about transportation improvement, including the data, and the responsibility to clarify technical questions about transportation improvement, including the data.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Transportation Management Association
term.shortDefinition: A voluntary group set up by employers or other entities to reduce vehicle trips within certain areas.(2) transportation management area.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Transportation Systems Management
term.shortDefinition: Low-cost improvements to make the transportation system work more efficiently, such as traffic signal coordination.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Transport Workers Union
term.shortDefinition: One of the major labor unions in the transit industry; membership is limited to operators, mechanics and other non-supervisory employees of the transit industry.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Trolley bus
term.shortDefinition: An electric, rubber-tired transit vehicle, manually steered, propelled by a motor drawing current through overhead wires from a central power source not on board the vehicle. Also known as "trolley coach" or "trackless trolley".
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Trust Fund
term.shortDefinition: Funds collected and used by the federal government for carrying out specific purposes and programs according to terms of a trust agreement or statute. Trust funds are administered by the government in a fiduciary capacity and are not available for the general purposes of the government.
term.extDefinition: An example would be the Social Security and highway trust funds.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: United Transportation Union
term.shortDefinition: One of the major labor unions in the transit industry; membership is limited to operators, mechanics and other non-supervisory employees of the transit industry.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Urbanized Area
term.shortDefinition: An U.S. Bureau of Census-designated area of 50,000 or more inhabitants consisting of a central city or two adjacent cities plus surrounding densely settled territory, but excluding the rural portion of cities.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: United States Department of Transportation
term.shortDefinition: The federal cabinet-level agency with responsibility for highways, mass transit, aviation and ports; headed by the secretary of transportation.
term.extDefinition: The DOT includes the Federal Highway Administration and the Federal Transit Administration, among others. There are also state DOTs (WashDOT in Washington)
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: value
term.shortDefinition: Something a person cares deeply about
term.extDefinition: A value is something (usually a principle or quality) that has intrinsic merit for a particular person. That is, they consider it to be worth having regardless of whether or not it has other benefits. They are basic desires and drives which govern behavior. Values in this sense are highly abstract, and to be useful in decision making, they must be framed in terms of some specific goals which embody them.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Merriam-Webster Online Dictionary
Meyer and Miller, 2001, pg 212
Drew & Nyerges, Journal of Risk Research 2004, p 44.

term.name: Van
term.shortDefinition: A 20-foot long or shorter vehicle, usually with an automotive-type engine and limited seating normally entered directly through side or rear doors rather than from a central aisle.
term.extDefinition: Used for demand response, vanpool, and lightly patronized motorbus service.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Vanpool
term.shortDefinition: An arrangement in which a group of passengers share the use and cost of a van in traveling to and from pre-arranged destinations together.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Variable Cost
term.shortDefinition: A cost that varies in relation to the level of operational activity.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: vehicle miles
term.shortDefinition: This term helps pin down the numbers. Reducing VMT can help ease traffic congestion and improve air quality.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: weight
term.shortDefinition: A measure of the heaviness of an object, or the relative importance given to something.
term.extDefinition: A number of factors may be considered in decision making, but they may not all carry equal weight in terms of determining the final outcome. Different factors have different weights, and this changes their ultimate importance to the decision. Weight is assigned according to the situation, and is not inherent to any factor.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: American Heritage Dictionary, 4th Ed.

term.name: Zone Fares
term.shortDefinition: A system of fares where a transit system's service area is divided into zones within which specified rates or fares apply.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: Surface Transportation Program
term.shortDefinition: One of the key capital programs in ISTEA. In the works of the STPP, it provides flexibility in expenditure of "road" funds for transit modes, as well as for pedestrian and bicycle facilities.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Mineta Transportation Institute Glossary. The Norman Y. Mineta International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies. Accessed 2006/07/12.

term.name: air rights
term.shortDefinition: the right to the use of air space over property owned by another. Often air rights are granted for buildings or other uses above or below transportation facilities
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: alternatives analysis
term.shortDefinition: Detailed study and assessment of the various options available for the purpose of selecting one for implementation. Ideally, all feasible alternatives will be investigated.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: fringe
term.shortDefinition: The portion of a municipality immediately outside the central business district or the portion of an urban area outside of a central city or cities (urban fringe) that is characterized by a variety of business, industrial, service, and some residential activity.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: coverage area
term.shortDefinition: In transit operations, the geographical area that a transit system is considered to serve, normally based on acceptable walking distances (e.g., '14 mile, 0.4 km) from loading points. For suburban rail transit that depends on automobile access (park and ride or kiss and ride), coverage may extend several miles. service.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: auto-free zone
term.shortDefinition: An area in which normal automobile traffic is prohibited. Vehicular traffic is restricted to public transit, emergency vehicles, taxicabs, and delivery of goods (the latter usually confined to certain time periods), or some combination thereof.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: auto-restricted zone
term.shortDefinition: An area in which vehicular traffic is regulated by time of day and type of vehicle. Normal automobile traffic and, sometimes, delivery of goods are limited to certain times; public transit, emergency vehicles, and (usually) taxicabs are permitted unrestricted access.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: ARZ
term.shortDefinition: An area in which vehicular traffic is regulated by time of day and type of vehicle. Normal automobile traffic and, sometimes, delivery of goods are limited to certain times; public transit, emergency vehicles, and (usually) taxicabs are permitted unrestricted access.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: base period
term.shortDefinition: In transit, the time of day during which vehicle requirements and schedules are not influenced by peak-period passenger volume demands (e.g., between morning and afternoon peak periods).
term.extDefinition: In transit, the time of day during which vehicle requirements and schedules are not influenced by peak-period passenger volume demands (e.g., between morning and afternoon peak periods). At this time, transit riding is fairly constant and usually low to moderate in volume when compared with peak-period travel.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: basic operating unit
term.shortDefinition: In rail rapid transit, the smallest number of rapid transit vehicles that can operate independently in revenue service, usually one to three (exceptionally more) cars.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: block grant
term.shortDefinition: aid directed at broadly or functionally defined purposes. In comparison with directed grants, more reliance is placed on state initiative, local initiative, or both in this form of grant
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: bidder
term.shortDefinition: An individual, partnership, firm, corporation, or any acceptable combination thereof, or joint venture, that is submitting a bid.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: bunching
term.shortDefinition: With transit units, a situation that occurs when passenger demand is high and dwell times at stops are longer than scheduled.
term.extDefinition: With transit units, a situation that occurs when passenger demand is high and dwell times at stops are longer than scheduled. Headways become shorter than scheduled, and platoons of transit units (vehicles or trains) develop, with longer intervals between platoons. The same effect (one transit unit caught by the following) can also be caused by lack of protection from general road traffic congestion or by traffic signal timing. Bunching can become cumulative and can result in delay to passengers and unused capacity.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: bus bay
term.shortDefinition: A branch from or widening of a road that permits buses to stop, without obstructing traffic, while laying over or while passengers board and alight.
term.extDefinition: A branch from or widening of a road that permits buses to stop, without obstructing traffic, while laying over or while passengers board and alight. It is designed to allow easy reentry of the bus into the traffic stream; also known as a blister, bus duckout, bus turnout, or lay-by. 2. A specially designed or designated location at a transit stop, station, terminal, or transfer center at which a bus stops to allow passengers to board and alight; also known as a bus dock or bus berth. 3. A lane for parking or storing buses in a garage facility, often for maintenance purposes.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: bus mile
term.shortDefinition: one bus operated for 1 mile.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: capital costs
term.shortDefinition: Nonrecurring or infrequently recurring costs of long-term assets, Such as land, guideways, stations, buildings, and vehicles. These costs often include related expenses, for example, depreciation and property taxes.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: commuter rail
term.shortDefinition: A passenger rail car designed for commuter rail services. It usually has many more seats than a conventional long-distance rail passenger car.
term.extDefinition: A passenger rail car designed for commuter rail services. It usually has many more seats than a conventional long-distance rail passenger car. The car may be hauled by a locomotive, have a self-contained internal combustion engine, or be electrically propelled by power from a third rail or overhead wire.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: catenary
term.shortDefinition: A form of electric contact system in which the overhead contact wire is supported from one, or more longitudinal wires or cables.
term.extDefinition: A form of electric contact system in which the overhead contact wire is supported from one, or more longitudinal wires or cables (called messengers), either directly by hangers (simple catenary) or by hangers in combination with auxiliary conductors and clamps (compound catenary). Attachment of the contact wire to the messenger is made at frequent and uniform intervals to produce a contact surface nearly parallel to the top of the track rails.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: census block
term.shortDefinition: A geographic area bounded on all sides by some definable feature (usually streets).
term.extDefinition: As defined by the Bureau of the Census, a geographic area wholly contained within a census tract and bounded on all sides either by streets or by a combination of streets, natural features, wat;+ways, railways, transmission lines, or property lines of public and semipublic tracts. It is the basic unit for tabulation of urban data by the Bureau of the Census.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: central business district
term.shortDefinition: an area of high land valuation characterized by a high concentration of retail businesses, service businesses, offices, hotels, and theaters, as well as by a high traffic flow
term.extDefinition: As defined by the Bureau of the Census, an area of high land valuation characterized by a high concentration of retail businesses, service businesses, offices, hotels, and theaters, as well as by a high traffic flow. A CBD follows census tract boundaries; that is, it consists of one or more whole census tracts. CBDs are identified only in central cities of MSAs and other cities 14 central city command and control system with populations of 50,000 or more.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: centroid
term.shortDefinition: In planning, a point within a traffic zone or district that is chosen to be representative of the center of trip-making activities of the zone or district
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: commute
term.shortDefinition: Regular travel between home and a fixed location (e.g., work, school). The term is often applied only to travel in the direction of the main flow of traffic, to distinguish from reverse commute.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: reverse commute
term.shortDefinition: commute in the direction opposite to the main flow of traffic, for example, from the central city to a suburb during the morning peak.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: contracting
term.shortDefinition: A procedure followed by many organizations to let certain parts of the operation to private contractors, instead of having their own employees perform the work.
term.extDefinition: A procedure followed by many organizations to let certain parts of the operation to private contractors, instead of having their own employees perform the work. A frequent rationale for contracting is the idea that the work can be performed more efficiently and with less expense to the main organization.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: cost-benefit analysis
term.shortDefinition: An analytical technique that compares the societal costs: and benefits (measured in monetary terms) of proposed programs or policy actions
term.extDefinition: An analytical technique that compares the societal costs: and benefits (measured in monetary terms) of proposed programs or policy actions. Identified losses and gains experienced by society are included, and the net benefits created by an action are calculated. Alternative actions are compared to allow selection of one or more that yield the greatest net benefits or benefit-cost ratio.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: cost-effectiveness analysis
term.shortDefinition: An analytical technique used to choose the most effective method for achieving a program or policy goal.
term.extDefinition: An analytical technique used to choose the most effective method for achieving a program or policy goal. The costs of alternatives are measured by their requisite estimated monetary expenditures. Effectiveness is defined by the degree of goal attainment and may also (but not necessarily) be measured in monetary terms.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: cost-plus contract
term.shortDefinition: a contract in which the purchase price is determined on the basis of actual costs plus a predetermined and mutually agreed-on fee, either a lump sum or a fixed percentage of total costs.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: culvert
term.shortDefinition: Any drainage or service structure under a roadway or guideway with a clear opening of 20 ft (6 m) or less measured along the center of the roadway or guideway.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: guideway
term.shortDefinition: In transit systems, a track or other riding surface (including supporting structure) that supports and physically guides transit vehicles specially designed to travel exclusively on it.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: impact analysis
term.shortDefinition: Part of the transportation planning proces in which the effects of a proposed project are considered.
term.extDefinition: In transportation planning, that part of the process in which there is an evaluation of the effects of an existing or proposed transportation project on social, economic, and environmental factors or variables, for example, on air pollution, energy consumption, accidents, socioeconomic effects.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: impedance
term.shortDefinition: In transportation generally, any condition that restricts or discourages travel, or a measure of that condition. Time and costs are the factors usually considered, but others may also be examined.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: intermodal integration
term.shortDefinition: Service coordination between two or more different transportation modes. This arrangment may include joint (transfer) stations, coordinated scheduling, joint fares, and combined public information activities.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: mode
term.shortDefinition: A particular form of travel, for example, walking, traveling by automobile, traveling by bus, traveling by train.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: no-action alternative
term.shortDefinition: A planning option of leaving the situation as it already exists. Existing facilities and services are maintained, and existing transportation policies are continued. See also transportation system management alternative.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: do-nothing alternative
term.shortDefinition: A planning option of leaving the situation as it already exists. Existing facilities and services are maintained, and existing transportation policies are continued. See also transportation system management alternative.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: multimodal
term.shortDefinition: Concerning or involving more than one transportation mode, e.g., bicycles, pedestrians, transit vehicles, ferries, trains and personal vehicles.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: needs assessment
term.shortDefinition: In transportation planning, a technique of estimating the services and facilities needed to satisfy the potential demand for transportation service.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: operating costs
term.shortDefinition: The sum of all recurring costs (e.g., labor, fuel) that can be associated wilh the operation and maintenance of the system during the period under consideration. Operating costs usually exclude such fixed costs as depreciation on plant and equipment, interest paid for loans on capital equipment, and property taxes on capital items.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: citizen advisory committee
term.shortDefinition: An organized group of local people who supply their ideas and input to, for example, a particular transportation study or plan, a transit or paratransit operation, or a government agency.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: high-occupancy vehicle
term.shortDefinition: Any passenger vehicle that meets or exceeds a certain predetermined minimum number of passengers, for example, more than two or three people per automobile. Buses, carpools, and vanpools are HOV vehicles.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: diamond lane
term.shortDefinition: A high-occupancy vehicle lane physically marked by diamonds on the pavement and often indicated by diamond-shaped signs as well
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: high-occupancy vehicle lane
term.shortDefinition: A highway or street lane reserved for the use of high-occupancy vehicles
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: prospectus
term.shortDefinition: In transportation, a document that describes proposed activities in transportation planning over a specified period of time, predicts future conditions in the region, assigns responsibility for planning and implementing transportation services, and discusses transportation alternatives for the future.
term.extDefinition: A prospectus may also be a document presenting the qualifications and experience of a consultant.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: ramp metering
term.shortDefinition: The process of facilitating traffic flow on freeways by regulating the amount of traffic entering the freeway through the use of control devices on entrance ramps.
term.extDefinition: Also, the procedure of equipping a freeway approach ramp with a metering device and traffic signal that allow the vehicles to enter the freeway at a predetermined rate.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: feeder
term.shortDefinition: Local transportation service that provides passengers with connections with a major transportation service.
term.extDefinition: A feeder service is a local transit service that provides passengers with connections to main-line arterial service; an express transit service station; a rail rapid transit, commuter rail, or intercity rail station; or an express bus stop or terminal.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: terminal
term.shortDefinition: The end station or stop on a transit line or route, regardless of whether special facilities exist for reversing the vehicle or handling passengers.
term.extDefinition: An assemblage of facilities provided by a railroad or intercity bus service at a terminus or at an intermediate location for the handling of passengers and the receiving, classifying, assembling, and dispatching of trains or dispatching of buses; also known as a depot.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: commuter rail
term.shortDefinition: A passenger railroad service that operates within metropolitan areas on trackage that usually is part of the general railroad system.
term.extDefinition: The operations, primarily for commuters, are generally run as part of a regional system that is publicly owned or by a railroad company as part of its overall service. In some areas it is called regional rail.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: interurban rail
term.shortDefinition: Electric rail transit service between cities and towns that are fairly close to each other.
term.extDefinition: This mode usually operates on private rights-of-way that are longitudinally physically separated (by curbs, barriers, grade separation, etc.) from other traffic but that have grade crossings for other vehicles and pedestrians, including regular street intersections. Sections of line in cities may run along streets or median strips.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: bus rapid transit
term.shortDefinition: An inexact term describing a bus operation that is generally characterized by operation on an exclusive or reserved right-of-way that permits high speeds.
term.extDefinition: It may include reverse lane operations on limited access roads. Strictly speaking, rapid transit designates operations entirely on exclusive right-of-way; thus bus rapid transit might be more appropriately called semi-rapid.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: transportation disadvantaged
term.shortDefinition: people whose range of transportation alternatives is limited, especially in the availability of relatively easy-to-use and inexpensive alternatives for trip making. Examples include the young, the elderly, the poor, the disabled, and those who do not have automobiles.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: trolleybus
term.shortDefinition: An electrically propelled bus that obtains power via two trolley poles from a dual (positive and negative) overhead wire system along routes. It may be able to travel a limited distance on battery power or an auxiliary internal combustion engine. The power-collecting apparatus is designed to allow the bus to maneuver in mixed traffic over several lanes.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: Department of Housing and Urban Development
term.shortDefinition: A cabinet-level federal agency whose responsibilities include community development programs, such as improved community facilities and services, assistance to nonprofit entities, and acquisition and rehabilitation of publicly owned real property.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

variations.variation: Dept. of Housing and Urban Development

term.name: Department of Labor
term.shortDefinition: A cabinet-level federal agency whose responsibilities include waivers of the labor protection provisions of Section 13(c) of the Urban Mass Transportation Act of 1964, as amended.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: Environmental Protection Agency
term.shortDefinition: An independent federal agency in the executive branch whose responsibilities include development and enforcement of national air quality emission standards and support of antipollution activities by state and local governments.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: National Transportation Safety Board
term.shortDefinition: An independent agency of the federal government whose responsibilities include investigating transportation accidents and conducting studies, and making recommendations on transportation safety measures and practices to government agencies, the transportation industry, and others.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: zoning
term.shortDefinition: The division of an area into districts, and the public regulation of the character and intensity of use of the land and improvements thereon.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: air pollution
term.shortDefinition: The presence of unwanted material in the air in sufficient amount and under such circumstances as to interfere significantly with human comfort, health, or welfare, or with full use and enjoyment of property.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: Gray, Benita H., ed. Urban Public Transportation Glossary. Washington, D.C.: Transportation Research Board, 1989.

term.name: privatization
term.shortDefinition: Privatization is the process of transferring property from public ownership to private ownership and/or transferring the management of a service or activity from the government to the private sector. Privatisation can be partial or complete. It may also carry conditions as to the change in ownership.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: "Privatization." Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia. 10 Jul 2006, 00:43 UTC. Wikimedia Foundation, Inc. 15 Jul 2006

term.name: appropriations
term.shortDefinition: In general, appropriations are moneys set aside for some specific use. The legislature must approve an appropriations bill for the expenditure of tax money by the government, usually for a specific purpose and period of time.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: "Appropriations", in WordNet 2.1, Princeton University, 2005.

term.name: right-of-way
term.shortDefinition: Either the privilege (granted by law, permit, or easement) to travel through another person's land, or, in traffic, the principle which determines which vehicle has precedence when more than one vehicle is trying to occupy the same space.
term.creator: admin

source.citation: "Right-of-Way", in WordNet 2.1, Princeton University, 2005.
